job_title: Shift Supervisor Rx in San Antonio, TX
pros: Benefits for full-time employees. High turnover rate so if you stick it out, you'll eventually get all the hours you want and maybe even overtime. You'll get an extra dollar if you pick up any shifts in the pharmacy which still will not be as much as a pharmacy tech just starting out makes. They make $16 an hour here in Texas. You'll get a great chance to test out your patience dealing with all the customers, the higher-ups, attitude, coupons, etc. (good luck)
cons: This company wants you to be an expert on EVERYTHING without giving you adequate training as a front store employee. You must learn all functions of the register, all functions of the self checkout, learn how to make every single photo item that we offer (there's a lot) while also learning how to use the 6+ different photo machines to do all the photo orders on. You will be consistently understaffed. There will be a skeleton crew at all times and when the store manager asks for help, they will get laughed at by their bosses and all the other store managers in the district suffering from the same issues. You will need to become a salesman and push people to upgrade their membership to a service nobody wants to pay for. You will deal with a lot of theft and a lot of really sketchy people in some areas. You might even get stabbed. You will get yelled at, a lot. Mostly by customers and patients. And if you live in Texas, you will have to do all these things while being paid only $13 an hour.

Inaccurate inventory management. The system is broken from the top down

Blame others is their way of life.

The CEOs outrage is purely theatric. What else is a powerful woman CEO supposed to say to the Media when something like that happens right underneath her nose. 

Absolutely the most horrible and entitled customer base on the planet
Health benefits are a joke considering it’s a healthcare company. It might look good on paper but wait until you get your first bill from the doctor
Unsustainable business model and Wall Street knows it

job_title: Store Manager Rx in Rochester, NY
pros:
If you swallow the corporate Koolaid and are cool with selling your team a load of BS, you will do well in this company.

You will learn leadership and management skills that will serve you well as you transition into a better company than CVS.
cons:
No work/life balance.

Store Managers are exploited. You must work 45 hours per week and your salary is based off of those 45 hours; however, you do not get a penny for any time over those 45 hours. When you take into account that your 
"breaks" are already factored into the MySchedule system, you are really in your store for 49 hours per week if you do the minimum.

Extremely low Front Store payroll means that you WILL work more than 45 hours per week if you want your store to look good and be operationally sound.

Front Store Managers who promote to District Leader are on a different pay scale than Pharmacy Managers promoted to district leader. District Leaders who come from the RX receive a base salary of $145-150,000 per year, while DLs who come from the front store earn a base salary around $80-85,000 (both will be higher in big city markets like Boston or NYC). What kind of incentive is that? Unfair and discriminatory against the FS.

pros: It would be a nice company to work for if the company was more consistent in vetting store managers for character and the union actually represented the workers instead of waiting until it's too late to address complaints.
cons: Managers get shuffled from store to store, with dramatic changes management styles getting inflicted on employees as a result. My last experience with the company was so bad I chose to get out of retail altogether, forever, and am now working in health care. This wasn't because of policy issues, but because after the manager who hired me was transferred, she was replaced by one whose abusive behavior left me with a pattern of nightmares that took years to go away.

review_title: Decent Pay... Job Security... Stability... as long as you are developing leaders
pros: Compensation is pretty good as of the last few years - competitive. Depending on your manager you have above you will really set your place in the store. They begun developing new systems and undertaken practices other big name stores have done... newer equipment as well. As stores develop and expand, there is much room for growth in upper management roles. Keep striving go be the best version of yourself!
cons: Hours... Hours.... HOURS. As a manager, taking a loss of hours is painful to keep operations together along driving customer service. You will drag on one or the other. And if it’s operations, you will be taking short cuts. Lack of hours generates a harder and strenuous work load on your team. With the addition of assisted self-check outs, has relieved issues but hard to drive customer service effectively... along with other programs that customers may ask about such as Carepass.

review_title: Small Box Retail.....just an Avg job at best that pays the bills
pros: Well, it is small box retail 8-10 person Front Store staff and I will not sugar coat it....it is tough to achieve all the expectations on a skeleton crew. If you are not a hands on, face right in the middle of the whole daily grind operation..... you wont do well. Office a half hour a day and you are off and running! Two people on duty on the Retail side 5 days...you get an extra body for Freight delivery day and Ad set day each week and that is all. You have to like to run, run, run! Pro's in retail these days? Now that is a hard question to find an answer to. I would just say an average job at best 5 on scale of 10.
cons: Run and operation on a real razor thin payroll. Sometimes the only person in the building early morning or late night. Very small staff.... Store Mgr does much of the hourly work or the operation cannot run efficiently. The usual thin staff retail grind. A skeleton staff where Corporate always looks to cut another hour out..... but still same high expectations for service scores and hitting metrics.

pros: Great place to gain experience.
cons: Super lenient because anyone can call off for multiple days in a row with no consequences, work hard for such little pay, does not raise your pay after getting certified. Also, when I was in my 3rd trimester of pregnancy, I was scheduled over 50 hours because there were only 2 technicians left. I also did not get a lunch on multiple occasions during my pregnancy while working 10 hour days and constantly standing on my feet. When I came back after my maternity leave, they raised everyone’s pay but mine , so new employees were making more than the lead technician who was there for 3+ years.

review_title: CVS is no different than Amazon and treats employees terribly
pros:
Can do a Roth-IRA and 401k+ with Vanguard while part-time.
Can get dental for $40/yr while part-time.
Can be fun with the right coworkers.
cons: Dramatic cut of hours beginning of every year and can make you part-time instead of full-time. No guarantee of full time hours. Ridiculous metrics to achieve and metrics seem to change and go back and forth to new/old ways every year. Until recently pharmacist never got a break. Training is absolutely terrible and never gives proper time to learn or have consistent training so each new hire is at a different level of knowledge of what to do. Will give store and pharmacy managers decent bones each March and gives terrible raises to everyone else in July. Any money made by the company just goes straight to the top at corporate and little for any management position at retail level. Everyone else is screwed. No incentive to get promoted or available options to move up in the company is extremely limited in pharmacy. Especially technicians in the pharmacy. Will go through hassle of hiring and training new people (that ends up hurting the store and patients bc lack of experience and increase in making mistakes)  than try to communicate and understand why experienced workers need to be paid more to stay. But will then yell at manager for not hiring "talent" when store starts to do bad. The "talent" that they're asking for and expecting with new hires is literally only obtainable from workers with experience of the job and the system used in the pharmacy. No transparency between management and team and expect it to be the same with corporate and upper management in retail stores. Constantly changing and updating system and never giving proper training or resources to try and understand in your own the new changes. I could go on but don't want to get riled up about how terrible this company is

pros: Good salary, easy to use computer system.
cons: Constantly adding new tasks while at the same time cutting hours. My store's volume has gone up since last year but have had 80 tech hours cut out of budget. This requires everyone to work in over drive from the second they walk into the pharmacy until they leave. We are losing all of our good employees and the hiring process is more than ridiculous to get new employees hired. We have no voice at all to the point that we don't speak up at all about problems because we know our DMs are powerless to effect any kind of change. We are required to make counseling phone calls and counsel customers at check out, something that I feel is really important but the RPH hours given don't reflect this mandate so we have to just do the best we can rushing people through and praying the conversations are not to in depth. I find myself avoiding eye contact with customers because one question could put me behind causing an entire page to "red"(even though no one is waiting for these prefills) which will affect your monthly scores. No matter how hard you work it will never be enough.

pros:
Remote work helps with schedule flexibility. 
It's a nice place to gain experience if you didn't have much of it.
Most co-workers are pleasant to work with.
cons:
Benefits: poor medical benefit - very high deductible at $3375 for individual and low employer HSA contribution at $500. If you have a family it's a lot worse because the full out of pocket max is 13500. You can get a slightly richer plan but you'll have to pay more to make up for it. Contribution is not great either for such a poor plan. Dental is not covered - employees have to pay the full premium. 
Salary: probably below market by at least 20% on average.
Work life balance: it's a hit and miss. If you're lucky to be with an understanding and thoughtful manager who knows how to give you just the right amount of workload then you're in good shape. Some just cares about meeting the number and load you up with as many cases as they want without much thought about how it stresses you out during the busy season.

review_title: CVS is ruining the Pharmacy profession
pros: Can't really think of any to be honest.
cons: The entire drive through pharmacy ideology has destroyed the profession. I understand that those that are really sick don't want to get out of their car, but by having time limits, we are now compared to fast food workers. Pharmacists have doctorates, they complete a minimum of 7 years of higher education and pass board certification just to show up to shift already behind on filling quota and a line of customers. The reduction of Pharmacist and tech hours has made a joke of this once respected healthcare profession.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Chandler, AZ
pros:
Great people
Permanent WFH
Great hours
Decent pay 
Ok benefits
cons:
They say you will get 6 weeks of training but what you really get is 2.5 weeks of learning a ton of information once, with no practice, and then being set loose on actual members. 

You can not switch positions for 6 months. They would rather have you quit and reapply for a new position (waste of money if you ask me ) thank move you to a position that you maybe better suited for. 

Lots of angry people that you really have no way to help -you are told to not remember anything but to research everything but researching tool is one of the most confusing things ever. 

From the moment you get out of training they want you to be talking call for 100% of shift. There is a button your supposed to be able to use for after call work (to type notes and regroup after bad calls) but then are told you are not allowed to use it 

Peers get to listen to your calls and tell you how to do it better. 

Only interaction I ever had with my supervisor was through chat. Not even so much as a zoom meeting to Introduce themselves or get to know any of the people underneath them.

cons: They have meetings telling you how many more millions the company is making every month and then cut your hours so that you are doing more and more of the work yourself, not managing. At most you have 2 people in the store but if someone calls in sick, forget it, you're by yourself and wont be able to leave the cash register so plan on working an extra day or 2 to make up all of the work you cant get to. This impacts your ability to help customers exactly the way you think it would, so forget meeting the impossible goals and metrics. Since you have no time to train employees but have to depend on them to do the work of 2 people they eventually decide the stress isnt worth it and leave, so expect to always be hiring. If you do somehow manage to keep an employee around long enough to be helpful to you, upper mgmt will just pressure you to find reasons to write them up and fire them so that they dont cost them too much in salary and/or benefits. They try to use their scheduling system so that employees dont quite qualify for it anyway. I have no idea why anyone works for or shops at cvs. They've broken quite a few privacy laws bc they are cheap, have the highest prices and worst customer service, and the pharmacy techs are definitely gossiping about you.

Every business decision is made to maximize profits for the shareholders, even if it endangers patients and employees.

Dreaded going to work every day because I knew I’d be yelled at by at least 1 patient for things out of our control (like wait times, out of stocks, long hold times, etc.) Expecting 1-2 people in the pharmacy to cover drop off, pick up, production, verification, vaccines, testing, AND answer the phones is not only unrealistic, it’s detrimental to patient safety.

review_title: work life balance is off. life takes a back seat
pros: There is holiday pay. You're on your own to figure out metrics, lie, cheat, steal, or have a low volume store to meet them.
cons: Only concerned with metrics. CVS does not care about its employees or patients. They push you to your maximum to meet metrics then they increase metrics. Always moving the target just out of reach. I would skip lunches and breaks for years to meet metrics. They are not attainable if you're working for free to achieve them. It is no secret management knows their targets are not reasonable and pharmacists are working for free on days off, before or after work to meet them. The stress is HIGH. Some new stores and low volume stores are not as stressful but those are few and far between. Why is it fair a busy store pharmacist works 60 hours a week, gets paid for 40 hours a week. While a newly open store (low volume) pharmacist has 10-20 hours of actual work and gets paid for 40 hours, meets all metrics because they have the time and less stressful environment to achieve them. CVS has continually cut technician hours in busy stores year after year, forcing 10 plus year technicians to quit. Replacing them with new hires, they expect to have the expertise and speed of a 10 year technician in a couple of weeks. Unrealistic, unreasonable, record profits for corporate, poor home life after have stressful work life.

job_title: Supervisor Specialty Customer Care in Buffalo Grove, IL
pros: Decent benefits, job stability, great staff and colleagues. I never had an issue requesting PTO. My manager did not micro manage.
cons: CSR to Supervisor ration is insane. Usually 30+:1. You will be overworked and underpaid. It’s impossible to successfully manage this many people and provide proper follow up and feedback to your staff. Department is extremely unorganized even prior to covid. Management was nearly non existent leaving the department to be ran by supervisors. Call centers have a high attrition rate but it’s even higher here due to the lack of organization. Get ready to learn HR onboarding tasks because that was also put on supervisors when new hires transition to the call center floor there was no standard operating procedure being followed or created. Suggestions were never taken seriously and team meeting and calibrations were literally non existent. Dealing with the types of escalations in specialty pharmaceuticals is difficult as it is…lack of department organization makes it more difficult with no clear operating procedures are defined. If you work hard and are knowledgeable, you will work more while other supervisors sit back and relax with no repercussions.

review_title: Good opportunity if you have a good team
pros: When you have a good team and a good manager then you'll have a great experience. It is a good chance for new grads to learn and a good place to have as a first job, but there is little opportunity to network with other people in the company outside your team. You can get exposed to many sides of the business, but it is easy to tunnel in on just one things.
cons:
There are some managers/teams within CVS that make working there terrible. There was a particular manager that would constantly talk down to others and make you feel belittled. This manager was never reprimanded for their behavior even though this was known. They would put enormous pressure on coworkers. This led to lots of anxiety and a fear of making mistakes.

 Moving to wfh made training a lot more difficult and there were large gaps in communications within teams. After initially moving to wfh I did not even speak to my director for a full 8 months. 

The pay was lackluster and promotion opportunities were scarce unless you knew people from other teams. CVS is a cheap company there are a lot of things offered in other large companies that CVS does not do. CVS pretty much just offers the barebones to their employees

review_title: Take what you can learn there,  and run
pros:
- good starting pay
- diverse culture
- ample chance to make extra money working overtime
- Employees can work from home
- great stock options and 401k
cons:
- Veteran staff is "cheap labor" and often new hires will make more
- Crazy hours 
- toxic work environment 
- horrible pay increases
- you don't always get a raise if you make senior, but they seek you have a higher ceiling for bonuses
- change in work with little training
- Management treats employees like spoiled children with toys. They play with them until they break. Once they break you they throw a fit, and then replace you. 
- frequent layoffs/ firing
- excessively high turn around. Assume by the end of the first year, half the people in your training class will be gone 
- unrealistic goals/ expectations. Often half if not more can't meet metrics monthly on a staff of 100+ people
- management that is verbally abusive and calls people in their team words like "culprit" or "lazy", and if you complain they say it's tough love
- management, especially upper management is burned out. 
- this job means you will be professionally hated for a living. Nobody contacts a Grievance team to say you're doing a good job. Ever. 
- unfair yearly reviews... one year on a scale of 1-5 they were told nobody could get higher than a 2 REGARDLESS of performance. 
- High number of people take stress caused leave of absence
- Management will support a rotten apple over an excellent worker if they think the apple will go to HR
- Mandatory weekends and some holidays
- Crazy hours/OT. It's not uncommon to go from October to March without A SINGLE day off 
- Highly competitive environment, stepping on people to advance encouraged
- Many managers are promoted based on who they know, not what they know. 
- If you burn out, expect management to basically black list you regardless how good your metrics are. 
- it is not uncommon for case loads to be over 75 you are working at once, and expected to touch every 5 or less days
- Many people are burned out and don't care, they cut corners to make metrics just to try to save their jobs... but if you get caught, you WILL be fired. So either way you are out of a job.
- with the high turn over means whoever leaves, gets fired, goes on leave their cases must be reassigned... if you are good, expect to be dumped on a a reward

review_title: Company out of touch with front line workers
pros:
-Great medical insurance
-You learn how to tell if a corporate worker is lying to you
cons:
-Leadership is driven to be dishonest with frontline employees
-Sexism was a big issue in my district
-Employees are expected to do a lot of stuff throughout the store with little to no hours as well as strict instruction not to leave the front of the store. Corporate for some reason does not realize the contradiction.
-Colleagues are only invested in if they plan to be a store manager. Otherwise good employees are never developed into great ones. 
-the past year had store managers pulling teeth to stand up for staff health and safety in the middle of a pandemic and social unrest. 
-Corporate would always mishandle rollouts of new initiatives and programs, yet would blame store level employees for lack of expected results.

review_title: Enormous Workload for Just One Person
job_title: Front Store Associate in Williamsburg, VA
pros: I have a hard time trying to pick out the pros of working as a cashier here, the most I could give is that you have the opportunity to meet new people.
cons: The workload is much heavier, I had a manager tell me that CVS was the worst pharmacy to work at because corporate cuts corners to make more money. My store crowds all of our kiosks together which is not compliant with Covid Guidelines and poses a risk to our customers who are from an older age group. On top of that, as a transgender employee, I am still struggling to get my name correct in our internal systems despite having worked there for 4 months. As a part-time employee, I was promised a minimum of 20 hours a week and I've been working 9 hour work weeks. These stores are not clean, I have been finding dead bugs in our makeup totes and most product we receive has something spilled on it (it's usually hair products like oils or shampoo), and finally, corporate has found a way to exploit workers by firing a loss in sales if we don't enroll people in the Carepass program. I went from asking people to join Carepass when it was necessary, but now if I don't ask every customer I have to give them free product, despite my store making our end-of-year enrollment goal in the first month. CVS is a very whitewashed company, that being said my manager just hired the first black woman in our store that I've seen in since I started working here.
